Package algorithms.statistics

Class GeneralizedExtremeValue

  • java.lang.Object
    • algorithms.statistics.GeneralizedExtremeValue
  • public class GeneralizedExtremeValue
extends java.lang.Object
      Generate curves following the Generalized Extreme Value probability density
  function.
 The GEV is a.k.a. the Fisher-Tippett distribution (though some restrict the
 Fisher-Tippett to the Gumbel distribution).
 
                           (   (      ( x-mu))-(1/k))
                           (-1*(1 + k*(-----))      )
                  1        (   (      (sigma))      )   (      ( x-mu))(-1-(1/k))
  y = y_const * ----- * exp                           * (1 + k*(-----))
                sigma                                   (      (sigma))
 
  mu is  the location parameter
  sigma is the scale parameter and is > 0
  k is the shape parameter
 
 
  if k != 0,
      1 + (k * (x-mu)/sigma) > 0
 
 
  Let z = (x-mu)/sigma
 
  Extreme Value Type I (Gumbel):
                      1
      y = y_const * ----- * exp( -z -exp(-z))
                    sigma
      
      sigma > 0
      k = 0
 
  Extreme Value Type II (Frechet):
                      k     (sigma)^(k+1)      (   (sigma)^k)
      y = y_const * ----- * (-----)       * exp( - (-----)  )
                    sigma   (  x  )            (   (  x  )  )
 
      k  > 0, (1/k)>0
      sigma > 0
      x > 0
      if (1 + k*(x - mu)/sigma) <= 0, y = 0
 
  Extreme Value Type III (Weibull):
                      k     (x - mu)^(k+1)      (   (x - mu)^k)
      y = y_const * ----- * (------)       * exp( - (------)  )
                    sigma   (sigma )            (   (sigma )  )
 
                      k
        = y_const * ----- * (z)^(k+1) * exp( -1*(z)^k )
                    sigma
 
      k < 0, (1/k)<0
      sigma > 0
      x > 0
       if -(1 + k*(x - mu)/sigma) >= 0, y = 1
    first implemented in project https://github.com/nking/two-point-correlation w/ Copyright Climb With Your Feet and using The MIT License (MIT) then moved to this shared library project which has the same copyright and license.
    Author:
    nichole

    • Method Detail

      • fitUsingMethodOfProbabilityWeightedMoments

        public static double[] fitUsingMethodOfProbabilityWeightedMoments​(double[] x)
        calculate a rough estimate of GEV distribution parameters for the given x. Note that the methods works best for sample sizes > 50. 
         references:
     "Estimation of the Generalized Extreme-Value Distribution by the Method of Probability Weighted Moments"
    Hosking, Wallis, and Wood 1984
        Parameters:
        x - ordered statistic of an observed GEV distribution where X is ordered from min to max.
        Returns:

        Parameters:

        yConst - normalization factor
        Returns:

        generate a GEV curve w/ parameters k, sigma, and mu and then multiply it by yConst so that the highest peak has value yConst
        Parameters:

        sigma - scale parameter, > 0
        mu - location parameter
        yConst -
        Returns:

      • calculateFittingErrorSquared

        public static double calculateFittingErrorSquared​(GEVYFit yFit,
                                                  double xPoint)
             return the error in fitting the GEV curve

                                 | dy_fit |^2            | dy_fit |^2            | dy_fit|^2            |dy_fit|^2
       (err_y_fit)^2 =  (err_x)^2|--------|   + (err_k)^2|--------|   + (err_s)^2|-------|   + (err_m)^2|------|
                                 |   dx   |              |   dk   |              |  ds   |              |  dm  |
        Returns:

      • calculateWidthFittingError

        public static double calculateWidthFittingError​(GEVYFit yFit,
                                                double yMaxFactor)
              calculate the error in an area / height calculation for y=0 to y > yLimitFraction where y is
      yLimitFraction to to the right of the peak.  This is useful for determining errors for things
      like FWHM for example.
     
      For FWHM we have sum of f = sum(X_i*Y_i)_(i < yLimit)/ Y_i

          err^2 = xError^2*(Y_i/Y_i) = xError^2

          it reduces to the sum of the errors in x.  no pde's...
        Parameters:
        yFit -
        yMaxFactor -
        Returns:

      • inverseCdf

        public static double inverseCdf​(double p,
                                double location,
                                double scale,
                                double shape)
                         throws java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException
        calculate the inverse CDF of the GEV, that is, a random variate x given the probability alpha. 
             reference is from the book "Extreme Value Distributions, Theory and Applications"
     by Kotz and Nadarajah 2000, Section 2.2 Macleod (1989):
     when shape != 0:
         x = location + scale*(1 - exp(-shape * y))/shape
     when shape= 0
         x = location + scale * y
     where y = -log(-log(p));  0 < p < 1
        Parameters:
        p - random variate drawn from U(0,1) where U is the uniform distribution. NOTE that p must be greater than 0 and less 1, so consider using a number such as eps=1-11 up to 1e-16 for an offset from 0 or 1. In other words, p drawn from U(1e-16, 1. - 1e-16).
        location - parameter of the distribution function
        scale - parameter of the distribution function
        shape - parameter of the distribution function
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException

      • inverseCdf

        public static double inverseCdf​(double p,
                                double location,
                                double scale,
                                double shape,
                                java.security.SecureRandom rand)
        calculate the inverse CDF of the GEV, that is, a random variate x given the probability alpha. 
             reference is from the book "Extreme Value Distributions, Theory and Applications"
     by Kotz and Nadarajah 2000, Section 2.2 Macleod (1989):
     when shape != 0:
         x = location + scale*(1 - exp(-shape * y))/shape
     when shape= 0
         x = location + scale * y
     where y = -log(-log(p));  0 < p < 1
        Parameters:
        p - random variate drawn from U(0,1) where U is the uniform distribution. NOTE that p must be greater than 0 and less 1, so consider using a number such as eps=1-11 up to 1e-16 for an offset from 0 or 1. In other words, p drawn from U(1e-16, 1. - 1e-16).
        location - parameter of the distribution function
        scale - parameter of the distribution function
        shape - parameter of the distribution function
        Returns:

      • inverseCdf

        public static double[] inverseCdf​(double[] p,
                                  double location,
                                  double scale,
                                  double shape,
                                  java.security.SecureRandom rand)
        calculate the inverse CDF of the GEV, that is, a random variate x given the probability alpha. 
             reference is from the book "Extreme Value Distributions, Theory and Applications"
     by Kotz and Nadarajah 2000, Section 2.2 Macleod (1989):
     when shape != 0:
         x = location + scale*(1 - exp(-shape * y))/shape
     when shape= 0
         x = location + scale * y
     where y = -log(-log(p));  0 < p < 1
        Parameters:
        p - array of random variates drawn from U(0,1) where U is the uniform distribution. NOTE that p elements must be greater than 0 and less 1, so consider using a number such as eps=1-11 up to 1e-16 for an offset from 0 or 1. In other words, p elements drawn from U(1e-16, 1. - 1e-16).
        location - parameter of the distribution function
        scale - parameter of the distribution function
        shape - parameter of the distribution function
        Returns:

      • sampleRandomlyFrom

        public static double[] sampleRandomlyFrom​(double location,
                                          double scale,
                                          double shape,
                                          int nDraws)
                                   throws java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException
        randomly draw from the inverse CDF of the GEV to return points that follow a GEV distibution. 
             reference is from the book "Extreme Value Distributions, Theory and Applications"
     by Kotz and Nadarajah 2000, Section 2.2 Macleod (1989):
     when shape != 0:
         x = location + scale*(1 - exp(-shape * y))/shape
     when shape= 0
         x = location + scale * y
     where y = -log(-log(p));  0 < p < 1
        Parameters:
        location - parameter of the distribution function
        scale - parameter of the distribution function
        shape - parameter of the distribution function
        Returns:
        array of randomly drawn numbers from the GEV
        Throws:
        java.security.NoSuchAlgorithmException

      • sampleRandomlyFrom

        public static double[] sampleRandomlyFrom​(double location,
                                          double scale,
                                          double shape,
                                          int nDraws,
                                          java.security.SecureRandom rand)
        randomly draw from the inverse CDF of the GEV to return points that follow a GEV distibution. 
             reference is from the book "Extreme Value Distributions, Theory and Applications"
     by Kotz and Nadarajah 2000, Section 2.2 Macleod (1989):
     when shape != 0:
         x = location + scale*(1 - exp(-shape * y))/shape
     when shape= 0
         x = location + scale * y
     where y = -log(-log(p));  0 < p < 1
        Parameters:
        location - parameter of the distribution function
        scale - parameter of the distribution function
        shape - parameter of the distribution function
        Returns:
        array of randomly drawn numbers from the GEV
